title: Gallbladder Cancer
diagnosis_topic: Malignancy of the gallbladder often discovered incidentally
setup_script: A 65-year-old woman underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallstones. Final pathology reveals an incidental pT2 gallbladder adenocarcinoma invading the perimuscular connective tissue.

dynamic_flow.reply: No bile spillage; gallbladder removed intact; cystic duct margin negative on frozen section.
CT scan of chest, abdomen and pelvis shows no distant metastasis; MRCP shows no common bile duct involvement.
For T2 disease, hepatic bed resection (segments IVB/V) and lymphadenectomy of the hepatoduodenal ligament are recommended.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident refers to medical oncology
dynamic_flow.reply: Assess need for adjuvant chemotherapy based on final pathology.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays re-operation beyond 6 weeks
dynamic_flow.reply: Risk of tumor seeding and metastasis increases.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident considers simple cholecystectomy sufficient
dynamic_flow.reply: Inadequate for T2 lesions; recurrence risk high.
Cystic duct margin negative; no need for extrahepatic bile duct excision unless margin positive.
Five-year survival 60-80% if resected early; worse for higher stage disease.
CT scans every 6 months for 2 years then annually.
Chronic gallstones, porcelain gallbladder, gallbladder polyps and Salmonella carriage.
Discuss need for reoperation and potential complications such as bile leak or liver insufficiency.
Involvement of hepatobiliary surgeon, medical oncologist and nutritionist.

critical_decision_points: Interpretation of incidental gallbladder cancer pathology and staging
Indications for extended cholecystectomy with hepatic resection and lymphadenectomy
Timing of reoperation to minimize tumor spread
Postoperative surveillance and adjuvant therapy considerations
Patient counseling regarding prognosis and risk factors
